title-group.article-title: Home away from Home: Geography of Information and Local Investors

permissions.copyright-statement: Copyright Â© 2015 The Society for Financial Studies

abstract.p: We develop a 10-K-based multidimensional measure of firm locations. Using this measure, we show that firm-level information is geographically distributed and institutional investors are able to exploit the resulting information asymmetry. Specifically, institutional investors overweigh firms whose 10-K frequently mentions the investors' state even when those firms are not headquartered locally and earn superior returns on those stocks. These ownership and performance patterns are stronger among hard-to-value firms. Local investor performance increases with the degree of local bias and with the local economic exposure of portfolio firms. Overall, geographical variation in firm-level information generates economically significant location-based information asymmetry.

Similarly, Whole Foods Market is headquartered in Austin, Texas, but has a large number of stores and significant exposure in other states - for example, Massachusetts, Florida, and Colorado. Whereas our study focuses on the multidimensional nature of firm location, recent studies by Pool, Stoffman, and Yonker (2012) and Shu, Sulaeman, and Yeung (2012) examine the multidimensional nature of investor location and find that an investor's portfolio decisions are related to the location at which she was born and/or went to college, in addition to that at which she is currently employed.

Although we refer to annual reports as 10-K forms throughout the paper, we collect and employ data from three types of forms: 10-K, 10-KSB, or 20-F. The latter two forms correspond to small businesses and foreign issuers, respectively.

Appendix B provides more details on the information contained in the relevant sections of the annual financial reports, and Appendix C provides sample excerpts from some 10-K forms filed for the 1996 to 2008 sample period.

Our parsing algorithm would miss instances in which the 10-K filing mentions a city but not the state. We also would be unable to capture cases in which the 10-K filings use state abbreviations. Inspection of a randomly selected set of filings indicates that both cases are rare. Further, there is no reason to believe that certain types of firms or firms located in certain states are more likely to abbreviate states or mention only city names in their reports. Thus, the citation counts may be noisy, but the relative frequency measure across firms would not exhibit a systematic bias due to these exclusions.

In unreported analysis, we find that there is similar evidence of local bias in various subsamples of institutions defined using investor self-reported types or portfolio sizes. Our finding that large institutions have weaker local bias is consistent with previous evidence obtained using different samples, for example, mutual funds during an earlier period in Coval and Moskowitz (2001).

This performance measure is identical to the "Portfolio Change Measure" introduced by Grinblatt and Titman (1993) and referred to as the GT measure by Daniel et al. (1997). More precisely, the trading performance is calculated as the difference between the performance of the investor portfolio as reported at the end of the previous quarter and that of the investor portfolio as reported at the beginning of the previous quarter. Because the returns from the part of the portfolio that does not change over the quarter cancel out, the measured trading performance is solely attributed to the part of the portfolio that changes during the previous quarter.

The reduction in local HQ performance over time is consistent with the trend observed by Coval and Moskowitz (2001), in which the performance differential between local and nonlocal mutual fund holdings is not significant in the second half of their sample period (1985 to 1994), both statistically (r-statistic = 0.09) and economically (annualized performance differential = 0.04%). Sulaeman (2014) extends this analysis to 2005 and reports similar patterns. Bernile, Kumar, and Sulaeman (2014) report that the decline in HQ performance coincide with the reduction in local HQ bias of institutional investors.
